name: Paris
intro_vibe: The city of light, love, and timeless culture.

general_info.description: Paris is the capital and most populous city of France. Known worldwide for its art, fashion, gastronomy, and culture, it has been one of the world's most important and attractive cities for over 2,000 years.

safety: Watch for pickpockets on Metro Line 1 and around major tourist sites
Keep bags zipped and in front of you in crowded areas
Beware of distraction techniques (petitions, dropped items)
scams: The 'gold ring' scam at Sacré-Cœur (someone 'finds' a ring and asks you to buy it)
Petition scammers who distract you while an accomplice pickpockets
Overpriced taxis from airports - use official taxi stands or RER trains
transit: Metro is fast and efficient - buy a carnet (10 tickets) for savings
Use CityMapper or RATP app for navigation
Navigo weekly pass is worth it if staying 5+ days
Avoid taxis during rush hour - Métro is faster

must_eat.description: The quintessential French breakfast. A proper croissant should be flaky with visible layers (lamination), golden-brown exterior, and buttery interior. Never microwaved. Best enjoyed fresh in the morning with café au lait. Look for 'pur beurre' (pure butter) labels - avoid 'ordinaire' which uses margarine.

French law regulates what can be called a 'traditional baguette' - only flour, water, salt, and yeast. No preservatives. Parisians buy fresh bread daily (it goes stale quickly). A proper baguette has a crispy crust that shatters, chewy interior with irregular holes. Best eaten within 4 hours of baking.

Small, casual restaurants serving traditional French cuisine. Characterized by zinc-topped bars, chalkboard menus, and communal atmosphere. Order classics like steak-frites, coq au vin, or blanquette de veau. Lunch (déjeuner) is typically 12-2pm, dinner (dîner) starts at 7:30pm. Service is included - tipping is optional.

Cafés are social institutions where Parisians read, work, and people-watch for hours. Order 'un café' (espresso), 'un crème' (espresso with milk), or 'un café allongé' (americano). Prices vary: cheaper at the bar (au comptoir), more expensive seated (en terrasse). Linger as long as you want - no one will rush you.

France produces over 400 varieties of cheese. Visit a fromagerie (cheese shop) and ask for recommendations. Cheese course (plateau de fromages) comes after the main course, before dessert. Classic Parisian cheeses: Brie de Meaux, Comté, Roquefort, Chèvre. Serve at room temperature, never cold.

Wine is integral to French dining. Order by the glass (un verre), pichet (carafe), or bottle. House wine (vin de maison) is often excellent and affordable. Neighborhoods like the Marais have natural wine bars (bars à vin nature). Apéritif (pre-dinner drink) is customary - try kir (white wine + cassis).

must_see.description: Sculpture museum with beautiful gardens, less crowded than the Louvre. Home to 'The Thinker' and 'The Kiss'. The garden alone is worth the visit - perfect for a peaceful break from the city.

13th-century Gothic chapel with stunning stained glass windows depicting 1,113 Biblical scenes. Visit on a sunny day to see the colors at their most vibrant. Skip the line with Museum Pass or book timed entry online.

Trendy waterway perfect for picnics and people-watching. Locals gather on the canal banks with wine and cheese, especially on summer evenings. The neighborhood has vintage shops, hip cafés, and a more relaxed vibe than central Paris.

Dramatic hilltop park with waterfalls, cliffs, and panoramic city views. Less touristy than Luxembourg Gardens. Locals jog, picnic, and relax here. The Temple de la Sibylle on the cliff offers stunning views of Sacré-Cœur and Montmartre.

19th-century covered shopping arcades with vintage charm. Galerie Vivienne, Passage des Panoramas, and Passage Jouffroy are the most beautiful. These glass-roofed passages house antique shops, tea rooms, and specialty bookstores - a perfect rainy-day activity.
